definition: A switch type that moves straight down without any bump or click. Known for smooth keypresses, making them popular for gaming and fast typing.
example: I chose Gateron Yellow linear switches for my first build because I wanted a smooth, quiet gaming board.

definition: A switch with a noticeable bump partway through the keypress that lets you feel when the key registers. Popular for typing because the bump provides feedback without being noisy.
example: I switched to tactile switches for programming because the bump helps me know when a keypress registers without bottoming out.

definition: A switch that produces an audible click sound along with a tactile bump when pressed. Satisfying to type on but not recommended for shared or quiet spaces.
example: My coworkers asked me to stop using clicky switches in the office because the clicking was driving them nuts.

definition: A switch with built-in rubber dampeners that reduce noise on the downstroke and upstroke. Ideal for office use and shared spaces where noise is a concern.
example: I swapped in Cherry MX Silent Reds because I needed a silent switch for my office.

definition: A switch that uses magnets and sensors instead of physical metal contacts to register keypresses. Allows adjustable actuation points and has virtually unlimited lifespan since there are no parts that physically touch to wear out.
example: I got a Hall Effect board so I could set the actuation point to 0.1mm for rapid trigger in competitive FPS games.

definition: The cross-shaped (+) part of a switch that moves up and down and connects to the keycap. The stem's shape determines whether a switch is linear, tactile, or clicky, and its material affects smoothness and sound.
example: The stem on this switch is made of POM, which gives it a naturally smoother feel than nylon stems.

definition: The outer shell of a switch, made up of a top and bottom piece, that holds the stem and spring. Housing material (nylon, polycarbonate, etc.) significantly affects the switch's sound and feel.
example: I picked switches with nylon housings because they tend to produce a deeper, thockier sound than polycarbonate ones.

definition: The metal coil inside a switch that provides resistance and pushes the stem back up after a keypress. Spring weight (measured in grams) determines how heavy the keypress feels.
example: The 62g springs in these switches feel too heavy for me, so I'm going to swap them for 55g ones.

definition: A thin metal piece inside the switch that makes contact with the stem to register a keypress. The leaf is what actually sends the electrical signal to your computer when you press a key.
example: The tactile bump in this switch is created by the shape of the stem leg pressing against the leaf.

definition: The exact point during a keypress where the switch's leaf and stem connect to register the keystroke. This is where the electrical circuit completes and the key input is sent to your computer.
example: This switch has a higher contact point, so the key registers earlier in the downstroke.

definition: The amount of force (measured in grams) needed to press a key far enough to register a keystroke. Lower values (35-45g) feel light and effortless, while higher values (60g+) feel heavier and more deliberate.
example: The 45g actuation force on these switches is perfect for long typing sessions because my fingers don't get fatigued.

definition: The total force needed to press a key all the way down to the bottom. This is always higher than the actuation force since the spring compresses more. Heavy typists who bottom out keys should pay attention to this spec.
example: I bottom out every key when I type, so I look at bottom out force rather than actuation force when choosing switches.

definition: The total distance a key moves from the top of the keystroke to the very bottom, usually measured in millimeters. Standard MX switches have about 4mm of travel. Shorter travel means faster keypresses.
example: These long pole switches have only 3.5mm of travel instead of the standard 4mm, so bottoming out feels more abrupt.

definition: The distance a key moves from the resting position to the actuation point where the keystroke registers. Shorter pre-travel means faster input registration, which is popular for gaming.
example: Gamers often prefer switches with shorter pre-travel so their inputs register as quickly as possible.

definition: A switch stem with an extended pole on the bottom that hits the housing earlier, shortening total travel and creating a sharper, more defined bottom-out feel and sound. Popular for clacky sound profiles.
example: I love the sharp bottom-out of long pole switches — they give that crisp clack on every keystroke.

definition: Switches that come pre-lubed from the manufacturer. Quality varies widely between brands. Factory lube saves time but is rarely as consistent as hand-lubing, which many enthusiasts prefer.
example: The factory lube on these Gateron switches is actually decent, so I'm not going to re-lube them.

definition: Replacing the spring inside a switch with one of a different weight or type to change how heavy or light the keypress feels. A common and easy modification that can dramatically alter the typing experience.
example: I did a spring swap from 67g to 55g on all my switches and it made the board feel completely different.

definition: Replacing the stem of one switch with a stem from a different switch to combine characteristics from both. This is how famous combinations like the Holy Panda were originally created.
example: I put Halo True stems into Invyr Panda housings to make Holy Pandas — the tactile bump is incredible.

definition: A switch or keycap that uses the standard Cherry MX cross-shaped (+) stem design. Almost all modern mechanical keyboard switches and keycaps follow this standard, making them interchangeable.
example: Make sure your keycaps are MX-compatible before buying them, or they won't fit your switches.

definition: Thin sheets of material placed between the top and bottom housing of a switch to reduce wobble and change the sound. Films tighten up loose housings, making the switch feel and sound more consistent.
example: After adding switch films, the top housing wobble disappeared and each keypress sounds noticeably tighter.

definition: A deep, low-pitched sound that many keyboard enthusiasts consider the most desirable sound profile. Often described as a satisfying 'thock' on each keypress. Achieved through nylon housings, foam mods, and certain plate materials.
example: I added case foam and used nylon-housed switches to get that deep, thocky sound I've been chasing.

definition: A higher-pitched, sharper sound on each keypress. Often produced by polycarbonate housings, long pole stems, and aluminum or brass plates. Some people prefer clack over thock for its crispness.
example: The aluminum plate and long pole switches give this board an incredibly clacky sound that I love.

definition: A smooth, warm sound profile with a slightly muffled quality. Popularized by NovelKeys Cream switches. Often associated with POM housings and nylon materials that produce a pleasing, rounded sound.
example: NovelKeys Creams live up to their name — the creamy sound profile is warm and smooth on every keystroke.

definition: A lively, bouncy sound with a quick, snappy quality on each keypress. Poppy keyboards feel responsive and energetic. Polycarbonate plates and housings often contribute to this sound.
example: The PE foam mod transformed the sound from flat and dull to bright and poppy.

definition: A very quiet, dampened sound profile with minimal noise on each keypress. Achieved through foam modifications, silent switches, and dampening materials. Ideal for office or shared environments.
example: I stuffed the case with foam and used silent switches to get the most muted sound profile possible for my office.

definition: A clean, sharp sound that is well-defined on each keypress without excess resonance or rattle. Often associated with well-tuned stabilizers and metal plates.
example: After tuning my stabilizers, the spacebar went from rattly to perfectly crisp.

definition: An unwanted metallic ringing sound produced by the spring inside a switch, especially noticeable after releasing a key. Can be reduced by lubing the spring or using switches with extended springs.
example: These stock switches are super pingy — you can hear the spring ring after every keypress.

definition: An undesirable rough or gritty feeling and sound when pressing a switch, caused by friction between the stem and housing. Stock Cherry MX switches are often described as scratchy. Fixed by lubing.
example: The stock Cherry MX Blacks felt scratchy out of the box, but after lubing them they became buttery smooth.

definition: The overall sound character of a keyboard, determined by the combination of switches, plate material, case material, and modifications. Common profiles include thocky, clacky, creamy, and poppy.
example: I'm building this board specifically for a deep thocky sound profile, so I chose nylon switches and a PC plate.

definition: A recording or video demonstrating how a keyboard sounds while typing. Sound tests help buyers understand a keyboard's sound profile before purchasing. Found commonly on YouTube and Reddit.
example: I watched a dozen typing sound tests on YouTube before deciding which switches to buy.

definition: A low-profile keycap shape that is slightly sculpted for each row. The most popular keycap profile in the hobby, offering a comfortable balance between low height and ergonomic sculpting.
example: Cherry profile keycaps are my go-to because they're low enough for comfortable gaming but still sculpted for typing.

definition: A tall, spherical-top keycap profile with aggressive sculpting between rows. SA keycaps produce a deeper sound due to their height and are loved for their retro aesthetic, though some find them too tall.
example: The SA profile keycaps tower over my desk, but the retro look and deep sound are totally worth it.

definition: A uniform (non-sculpted) spherical-top keycap profile where every row is the same height. This makes keycaps interchangeable between rows, which is useful for non-standard layouts.
example: I used DSA keycaps on my Ortholinear board since every key is the same profile and can go in any position.

definition: A tall, deeply sculpted keycap profile designed by Matt3o, inspired by vintage terminal keyboards. Has a scooped top and dramatic row-to-row height changes. Typing on MT3 feels very deliberate and satisfying.
example: MT3 keycaps have the most aggressive sculpting I've tried — your fingers naturally nestle into each row.

definition: A uniform (non-sculpted) keycap profile with a flat top surface, slightly taller than DSA. Every key is the same shape, making them versatile for alternative layouts. A popular budget-friendly profile.
example: XDA keycaps are affordable and work great on my split keyboard since I can move keys around freely.

definition: The most common keycap profile found on prebuilt keyboards. Slightly taller and less sculpted than Cherry profile. If you have used a regular mechanical keyboard, you have likely typed on OEM keycaps.
example: The stock keycaps on most gaming keyboards are OEM profile, so that's what most people are used to typing on.

definition: A keycap printing method where dye is heat-pressed into the plastic, becoming part of the material itself. Dye-sub legends never wear off or fade. Limited to printing darker colors on lighter keycaps.
example: I prefer dye-sublimated PBT keycaps because the legends will never fade no matter how much I type.

definition: A premium keycap manufacturing method using two layers of plastic molded together to form the legends. The legends can never fade or wear away since they are a separate piece of plastic. Allows any color combination.
example: These doubleshot ABS keycaps have vibrant legends that will outlast the keyboard itself.

definition: Polybutylene terephthalate, a type of plastic used for keycaps. PBT keycaps are more durable, resistant to shine (oil buildup), and produce a slightly deeper sound compared to ABS. Most enthusiasts prefer PBT.
example: I always go with PBT keycaps because ABS gets shiny and greasy after a few months of heavy use.

definition: Acrylonitrile butadiene styrene, a common keycap plastic. ABS is smoother, allows more vibrant colors, and is used for most doubleshot keycaps. The downside is that ABS develops a shiny, greasy look over time from finger oils.
example: GMK keycaps are made from ABS, which is why they eventually develop that shiny, worn look on the most-used keys.

definition: The letters, numbers, and symbols printed or molded onto keycaps. Legend quality and durability depend on the production method. Doubleshot and dye-sub legends last the longest, while pad-printed legends wear off quickly.
example: The legends on my cheap keycaps wore off after six months, so I upgraded to doubleshot ones.

definition: A complete set of keycaps designed to cover an entire keyboard, often with extra keys for different layouts. Sets come in various profiles, materials, and colorways. High-end sets can cost $100-200+.
example: I just ordered a GMK keycap set in the Olivia colorway — it took 14 months to arrive from the group buy.

definition: A keyboard case machined from aluminum, providing excellent build quality, weight, and a premium feel. Aluminum produces a crisp, slightly higher-pitched sound profile. Most mid-to-high-end custom keyboards use aluminum cases.
example: The aluminum case adds over a pound of weight to the board, but the build quality and sound are worth it.

definition: A keyboard case made from clear or translucent polycarbonate plastic. PC cases produce a deeper, softer sound compared to aluminum and allow RGB lighting to shine through. Popular for see-through builds.
example: I went with a polycarbonate case because the translucent look with RGB underneath is stunning.

definition: A keyboard case made from layered sheets of acrylic, often frosted or clear. Acrylic cases diffuse RGB lighting beautifully and produce a hollow, somewhat resonant sound. Common in budget and DIY keyboard kits.
example: The frosted acrylic case makes the RGB underglow look like it's glowing from within.

definition: A keyboard plate made from aluminum that sits between the switches and PCB, holding the switches in place. Aluminum plates provide a firm, stiff typing feel with a crisp, bright sound signature.
example: The aluminum plate gives this build a stiff, no-nonsense typing feel with a sharp sound on every keypress.

definition: A keyboard plate made from polycarbonate that offers more flex than aluminum or brass plates. PC plates produce a deeper, softer sound and a bouncier typing feel, making them popular for gasket mount builds.
example: I chose a PC plate with flex cuts for maximum bounce — the typing feel is almost pillow-like.

definition: A keyboard plate made from the same fiberglass material used in PCBs. FR4 plates are lightweight, affordable, and offer moderate flex. They produce a balanced sound between the stiffness of aluminum and softness of PC.
example: FR4 is my favorite plate material because it offers a nice middle ground between stiff aluminum and flexy polycarbonate.

definition: A heavy, dense keyboard plate made from brass that provides a very stiff typing feel with a unique bright, pingy sound. Brass plates add significant weight and have a premium, luxurious feel.
example: The brass plate adds almost 200g of extra weight and makes every keypress feel incredibly solid and precise.

definition: Slots or cuts made in a keyboard plate to allow it to bend more during typing. Flex cuts reduce stiffness and create a softer, bouncier typing feel, especially popular with gasket mount boards.
example: The flex cuts in this plate let it bend noticeably when I press down, giving a really satisfying bounce.

definition: A mounting style where the plate is suspended between strips of soft gasket material (usually silicone or rubber) sandwiched between the plate and case. This isolates the typing surface for a softer, bouncier feel and reduced case ping.
example: The gasket mount on this board gives it a soft, cushioned typing feel that tray mount keyboards can't match.

definition: A mounting style where the plate screws directly to the top part of the case. Provides a firm, consistent typing feel with good sound. Less flex than gasket mount but more than tray mount. A proven, reliable design.
example: Top mount boards have a solid, consistent feel across the whole board that I really enjoy for typing.

definition: The most common and affordable mounting style where the PCB screws into standoffs on the bottom case. Simple and effective but can create uneven flex, with areas near screw points feeling stiffer than others.
example: My budget board uses tray mount, and you can definitely feel the stiff spots right where the screws are.

definition: A mounting style where the plate is sandwiched between the top and bottom case halves. The plate sits on the bottom case edge and the top case holds it down. Provides a uniform feel across the board.
example: Sandwich mount is simple and effective — the plate is held firmly between the two case halves with no screws touching it.

definition: A mounting style that uses rubber O-rings to cushion and isolate the plate from the case. Similar concept to gasket mount but uses ring-shaped dampeners. Creates a soft, bouncy typing experience.
example: The O-ring mount on this board gives it an incredibly bouncy, almost trampoline-like feel when typing.

definition: A design where the plate is built directly into the top case as one piece, rather than being a separate component. Common in budget keyboards. Provides a very stiff, rigid typing feel with no flex.
example: The integrated plate means you can't swap plate materials, but it keeps the cost down on budget boards.

definition: Refers to switches or stabilizers that clip directly onto the plate rather than the PCB. Plate-mount stabilizers are easier to install but cannot be swapped without removing all nearby switches first.
example: I had to desolder half the board to swap the plate-mount stabilizers, which is why I prefer screw-in PCB mount.

definition: Refers to switches or stabilizers that attach directly to the PCB. PCB-mount (5-pin) switches have two extra plastic legs for stability. PCB-mount (screw-in) stabilizers are preferred by enthusiasts for their stability.
example: Always get 5-pin PCB mount switches — you can clip the extra legs off if your board doesn't need them, but you can't add them.

definition: Applying lubricant (usually Krytox 205g0 for linears or Tribosys 3203 for tactiles) to switch components to reduce friction and noise. Hand-lubing switches is the single most impactful mod for improving smoothness and sound.
example: I spent four hours hand-lubing 70 switches, but the difference in smoothness and sound was absolutely worth it.

definition: Applying layers of painter's tape to the back of the PCB to change the sound profile. The tape reflects sound waves differently, often resulting in a deeper, more muted sound. A simple, free, and reversible mod.
example: Three layers of painter's tape on the back of the PCB gave this board a noticeably deeper, more marbly sound.

definition: Placing a thin sheet of PE (polyethylene) foam between the PCB and switches. This changes how sound resonates through the board, often creating a poppy, marble-like sound. Very popular and easy to do.
example: The PE foam mod completely changed the sound signature from hollow to poppy — one of the best free mods out there.

definition: Another name for the tape mod, named after the community member who popularized it. Involves applying masking or painter's tape to the back of the PCB. Often combined with other foam mods for best results.
example: I did the Tempest mod along with PE foam and the sound went from tinny to deep and full.

definition: Placing small strips of fabric bandage material on the PCB under the stabilizer housings to cushion the impact and reduce rattle. An early and simple mod for quieter, better-sounding stabilizers.
example: The Band-Aid mod is old school, but it still works great for cushioning the stabilizer impact on the PCB.

definition: Wrapping the stabilizer wire with a thin strip of bandage or fabric to eliminate wire rattle and ticking. Named after the community member who popularized it. One of the most effective stabilizer tuning techniques.
example: The Holee mod finally eliminated the tick sound on my spacebar stabilizer that nothing else could fix.

definition: Cutting or removing parts of the plate between certain switch positions to allow sections of the plate to flex independently. Creates a softer, more flexible typing feel in specific areas of the keyboard.
example: I did a force break mod on my aluminum plate to add flex where the alphas are — it types much softer now.

definition: Placing small rubber O-rings on keycap stems to shorten key travel and reduce the sound of bottoming out. A cheap, easy mod for quieter typing. Some dislike the mushy feeling it creates.
example: I put O-rings on my keycaps to quiet down the board, but the mushy bottom-out feel wasn't for me.

definition: The process of lubing, clipping, and modifying stabilizers to eliminate rattle and create a consistent, smooth feel on larger keys like spacebar, shift, and enter. Well-tuned stabs make a huge difference in sound quality.
example: Stabilizer tuning took my spacebar from rattly and mushy to perfectly smooth and consistent.

definition: Various foam materials (IXPE, Poron, EVA, silicone) placed inside the keyboard case, between the PCB and plate, or under the PCB. Foam reduces hollowness, dampens ping, and helps shape the overall sound profile.
example: I filled all the empty space in the case with foam and it completely eliminated the hollow, echoey sound.

definition: A keyboard PCB with sockets that allow switches to be inserted and removed without soldering. Hot-swap makes it easy to try different switches and is strongly recommended for beginners. Most modern kits offer hot-swap.
example: I got a hot-swap board so I could try out different switches without having to learn soldering.

definition: A keyboard where switches are permanently attached to the PCB using solder. Soldered builds provide a more secure connection and slightly different sound characteristics, but changing switches requires desoldering.
example: I went with a soldered build for the tighter switch-to-PCB connection, even though I can't easily swap switches.

definition: LED lights positioned on the south (bottom) side of each switch on the PCB. Preferred by enthusiasts because they avoid interference with Cherry-profile keycaps. Most modern custom PCBs use south-facing LEDs.
example: Make sure your PCB has south-facing LEDs if you plan to use Cherry profile keycaps, or you'll get interference.

definition: LED lights positioned on the north (top) side of each switch. Shine through keycap legends better but can cause interference with Cherry-profile keycaps on certain switches, resulting in a 'clack' on the upstroke.
example: My board has north-facing LEDs and Cherry profile keycaps, so I get an annoying clack on the upstroke of some keys.

definition: Printed Circuit Board - the main electronic board inside a keyboard that registers keypresses and sends signals to your computer. The PCB determines features like hot-swap support, LED placement, and programmability.
example: This PCB supports both hot-swap and QMK, so I can swap switches freely and program any key mapping I want.

definition: A community-organized pre-order where a product is manufactured only after enough orders are collected. Common for keycap sets and high-end keyboards. Delivery often takes 6-18 months. Products are usually cheaper than aftermarket.
example: I joined the group buy for GMK Olivia a year ago and my keycaps finally just shipped.

definition: A product that is currently available to buy and ship immediately, without waiting for a group buy. Many enthusiasts prefer in-stock items to avoid long wait times, even if they cost slightly more.
example: I'd rather pay a bit more for an in-stock keycap set than wait 12 months for a group buy to deliver.

definition: A survey or post (often abbreviated IC) where a designer gauges community interest before running a group buy. ICs let you vote on colorways, provide feedback on designs, and get notified when the group buy launches.
example: I filled out the interest check for that new keycap set and voted for the dark colorway option.

definition: Refers to the production round of a group buy product. R1 means first round (initial run), R2 means second round (re-run due to demand). Later rounds may include improvements or new colorways based on community feedback.
example: I missed R1 of these keycaps, but the designer announced R2 with two new colorways based on community feedback.

definition: Mechanisms that support wider keys (spacebar, shift, enter, backspace) to keep them level and prevent wobble. Poorly tuned stabilizers cause rattling sounds. Screw-in (PCB-mount) stabilizers are preferred over clip-in for stability.
example: My spacebar was rattling like crazy until I properly lubed and tuned the stabilizers.

definition: A compact keyboard layout with only the main alphanumeric keys, removing the function row, navigation cluster, and numpad. About 61 keys total. Functions are accessed through key layers. Popular for its minimalist look and desk space savings.
example: I switched to a 60% layout for the extra desk space, and I got used to using function layers within a week.

definition: A keyboard layout that adds arrow keys and a few navigation keys to a 60% layout, without a function row. About 66-68 keys. Considered the sweet spot between compactness and functionality by many enthusiasts.
example: The 65% layout is perfect for me because I need dedicated arrow keys but don't miss the function row.

definition: A keyboard layout that includes the function row (F1-F12) and arrow keys in a compact arrangement. About 82-84 keys. The most popular custom keyboard size because it keeps essential keys without taking up too much desk space.
example: I went with a 75% layout because I use F-keys for shortcuts at work but still wanted a compact board.

definition: Tenkeyless - a keyboard layout that removes only the number pad from a full-size keyboard, keeping the function row and navigation cluster. About 87 keys. Great for users who want familiar layout with more desk space for mouse movement.
example: A TKL gives me all the keys I need for productivity work without the numpad hogging desk space.

definition: A keyboard with all standard keys including the number pad, function row, and navigation cluster. About 104 keys. Preferred by users who frequently use the numpad for data entry, accounting, or number-heavy work.
example: I need a full-size keyboard for accounting because I'm entering numbers on the numpad all day.

definition: A compact layout that fits all the keys of a full-size keyboard (including numpad) into a smaller footprint by eliminating gaps between key clusters. About 99-100 keys. Great for numpad users who want a smaller board.
example: The 96% layout gives me a numpad without the wasted space — all the clusters are pushed together.

definition: An open-source keyboard firmware that allows deep customization of key mappings, macros, layers, and lighting. QMK is the most powerful firmware option but requires some technical knowledge to configure. Flashed via command line or QMK Toolbox.
example: I use QMK to set up custom layers so my 60% board can access every function key and macro I need.

definition: A user-friendly graphical tool for customizing keyboards that run QMK firmware. VIA lets you remap keys, create macros, and adjust lighting in real time through a simple web or desktop app. No coding required.
example: VIA makes it dead simple to remap keys — just open the app, click a key, and assign a new function.

definition: Polyoxymethylene (also called Delrin or acetal), a self-lubricating plastic used in switch stems and housings. POM's natural lubricity means switches using it tend to be smoother and require less lube. Produces a deep, thocky sound.
example: These POM-stemmed switches feel smooth even without lube thanks to the self-lubricating properties of the material.

definition: A common material used for switch housings and keyboard cases. Nylon housings produce a deeper, warmer sound compared to polycarbonate. Many enthusiasts prefer nylon-housed switches for thocky sound profiles.
example: I specifically sought out switches with nylon housings because I'm going for a deep, thocky sound.

definition: A transparent thermoplastic used for switch housings, keyboard cases, and plates. PC housings produce a higher-pitched, clackier sound than nylon. PC cases allow RGB light diffusion and have a unique acoustic character.
example: Polycarbonate switch housings give a brighter, clackier sound that pairs well with an aluminum plate.

definition: Ultra-high-molecular-weight polyethylene, an extremely smooth and self-lubricating plastic used in premium switch stems and housings. UHMWPE components require minimal lubing and provide exceptional smoothness.
example: UHMWPE stems are insanely smooth even bone-dry — the material practically lubes itself.

definition: The smallest common keyboard layout, removing the number row entirely along with function and navigation keys. About 40-48 keys. Everything is accessed through multiple layers. Requires significant adjustment but offers maximum desk space.
example: It took me two weeks to get comfortable with my 40% board, but now I type faster because my fingers never leave the home row.

definition: A compact full-size layout that includes a numpad but reduces spacing between key clusters. Similar to 96% but with a small gap between the main keys and numpad. Found in some vintage keyboards and modern customs.
example: The 1800 layout is like a 96% but with a tiny gap before the numpad, which makes it easier to find keys by feel.

definition: The most popular switch lubricant in the keyboard hobby, a thick PFPE grease ideal for linear switches. Applied to switch stems, housing rails, and springs for dramatically improved smoothness and sound. Too thick for tactile switches.
example: Krytox 205g0 on linear switches is a game-changer — the stems glide like butter after a proper application.

definition: A thinner lubricant popular for tactile switches because it improves smoothness without reducing the tactile bump. Less viscous than Krytox 205g0, making it harder to over-apply. Good for beginners who want a safer lube option.
example: I used Tribosys 3203 on my tactile switches because it smooths things out without killing the bump.
